intro: Peucedanum officinale, commonly known as cow parsley or wild chervil, is a biennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its hollow stems and aromatic, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbrella-shaped clusters, typical of the carrot family. Its seeds are small and oval, often used in traditional herbal medicine for their digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. The entire plant has a mild, anise-like fragrance, which contributes to its use in culinary and medicinal applications.
